entry.title: Expectation of absolute distance in Random walk

link.title: Expectation of absolute distance in Random walk

entry.content:
This blog, I will post my proof about the expectation of absolute distance in Random walk is ${\Theta(\sqrt{i})}$ at ${i}$th step.

Statement of Problem

Consider a sequence of $n$ flips of an unbiased coin. Let $H_i$ denote the absolute value of the excess of then number of HEADS over the number of TAILS seen in the first $i$ flips. Show that $E[H_i] = \Theta(\sqrt{i})$.

We can also treat is as a 1D random walk problem.

Idea of my proof

  1. Use the relation between Expectation and Variance to get the upper bound $\sqrt{i}$.

  2. Solve the recursive formula of $E[H_i]$, which can give us a sense of growth speed. We can prove the lower bound greater than ${C\sqrt{i}}$ by induction, where C ranges from $0$ to $1$.

Lemma 1: $\mathbb{E}[H_i]$ satisfies following recursive formula

\[ egin{equation} \mathbb{E}[H_i] = egin{cases} \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}] + rac{1}{2^{i-1}} inom{i-1}{(i-1)/2}, & n ext{ is odd,}\ \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}],& n ext{ is even.} \end{cases} onumber \end{equation}\]

Proof. By definition, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_i] &= \sum_{k=0}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert \Pr[k ext{ HEADS in first } i ext{ flips}] \ &= \sum_{k=0}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]
  • If $i$ is even and $i-1$ is odd. We have
\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_i] &= \sum_{k=0}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} \ & = 2 \cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} \ & = \vert -i + 2(i/2) \vert inom{i}{i/2} rac{1}{2^i} + 2 \cdot \sum_{k=i/2+1}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} \ & = 2 \cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} \ & = 2 \cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} (-i + 2k) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} + 2 \vert -i + 2i \vert inom{i}{i} rac{1}{2^i} \ & = 2 \cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} (-i + 2k) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} + rac{i}{2^{i-1}} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

And

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}] &= \sum_{k=0}^{i-1} \vert -i+1 + 2k \vert inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}} \ & = 2\cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} \vert -i+1 + 2k \vert inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2\cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} ( -i+1 + 2k ) inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}}\ \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

Then, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_i] - \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}] &= 2 \cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} (-i + 2k) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} + rac{i}{2^{i-1}} - 2\cdot \sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} ( -i+1 + 2k ) inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}} \ & = 2\left(\sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} (-i + 2k) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^i} - ( -i+1 + 2k ) inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2\left(\sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} rac{(-i + 2k)}{2^i} \left( inom{i-1}{k} + inom{i-1}{k-1} ight)- inom{i-1}{k} rac{( -i+1 + 2k )}{2^{i-1}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2\left(\sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} rac{(-i + 2k)}{2^i} inom{i-1}{k-1} + inom{i-1}{k} rac{( i -2 - 2k )}{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2\left(\sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} rac{(-i + 2k)}{2^i} inom{i-1}{k-1} - \sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} inom{i-1}{k} rac{( -i +2 + 2k )}{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2\left(\sum_{k=i/2}^{i-1} rac{(-i + 2k)}{2^i} inom{i-1}{k-1} - \sum_{j=i/2+1}^{i} inom{i-1}{j-1} rac{( -i + 2j )}{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2\left( rac{(-i + 2(i/2))}{2^i} inom{i-1}{i/2-1} - inom{i-1}{i-1} rac{( -i + 2i )}{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}} \ & = 2\left( 0\cdot inom{i-1}{i/2-1} - inom{i-1}{i-1} rac{i}{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}} \ & = 0 \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]
  • If $i$ is odd and $i-1$ is even. We have
\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_{i}] &= \sum_{k=0}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}} \ & = \sum_{k=0}^{(i-1)/2} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}} + \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}} \ & = 2\cdot \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i} \vert -i + 2k \vert inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}}\ & = 2\cdot \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} ( -i + 2k ) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}} + 2 \cdot ( -i + 2i ) inom{i}{i} rac{1}{2^{i}} \ & = 2\cdot \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} ( -i + 2k ) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}} + rac{i}{2^{i-1}} \ \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

And

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}] &= \sum_{k=0}^{i-1} \vert -i+1 + 2k \vert inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}} \ & = 2 \cdot \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} (-i+1 + 2k) inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

Then, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_i] - \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}] &= 2\cdot \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} ( -i + 2k ) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}} + rac{i}{2^{i-1}} - 2 \cdot \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} (-i+1 + 2k) inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}} \ & = 2 \cdot \left(\sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} ( -i + 2k ) inom{i}{k} rac{1}{2^{i}} - (-i+1 + 2k) inom{i-1}{k} rac{1}{2^{i-1}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2 \cdot \left(\sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} rac{( -i + 2k )}{2^{i}} \left( inom{i-1}{k} + inom{i-1}{k-1} ight) - inom{i-1}{k} rac{ (-i+1 + 2k) }{2^{i-1}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2 \cdot \left(\sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} rac{( -i + 2k )}{2^{i}} inom{i-1}{k-1}+ inom{i-1}{k} rac{ (i-2 - 2k) }{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2 \cdot \left(\sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} rac{( -i + 2k )}{2^{i}} inom{i-1}{k-1} - \sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} inom{i-1}{k} rac{ (-i+2 + 2k) }{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2 \cdot \left(\sum_{k=(i+1)/2}^{i-1} rac{( -i + 2k )}{2^{i}} inom{i-1}{k-1} - \sum_{j=(i+3)/2}^{i} inom{i-1}{j-1} rac{ (-i+2 j) }{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = 2 \cdot \left( rac{( -i + 2((i+1)/2) )}{2^{i}} inom{i-1}{(i+1)/2-1} - inom{i-1}{i-1} rac{ (-i+2 i) }{2^{i}} ight) + rac{i}{2^{i-1}}\ & = rac{1}{2^{i-1}} inom{i-1}{(i-1)/2} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

Hence, we prove the recursive formula

\[ egin{equation} \mathbb{E}[H_i] = egin{cases} \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}] + rac{1}{2^{i-1}} inom{i-1}{(i-1)/2}, & n ext{ is odd,}\ \mathbb{E}[H_{i-1}],& n ext{ is even.} \end{cases} onumber \quad \quad \quad \square \end{equation}\]

Theorem 1: $\mathbb{E}[H_i] = \Theta(\sqrt{i})$.

Proof.

  1. First, Let’s show $\mathbb{E}[H_i] \leq \sqrt{i}$ Denote the random variable $X_j, j = 1,2,\cdots, i$ as below
\[ egin{equation} X_j = egin{cases} 1 & ext{HEAD is seen in } i ext{th flip}\ -1 & ext{TAIL is seen in } i ext{th flip}\ \end{cases} onumber \end{equation}\]

It’s easy to have $H_i = \vert \sum_{j=1}^i X_i \vert $, $\mathbb{E}[X_i]=0$ and we know $X_1,X_2,\cdots,X_i$ are pairwise independent. By the definition of variance $\mathbb{D}[H_i]$, we have $\mathbb{D}[H_i] = \mathbb{E}[H_i^2] - (\mathbb{E}[H_i])^2$. Then we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} (\mathbb{E}[H_i])^2 = \mathbb{E}[H_i^2] - \mathbb{D}[H_i] \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

Because $X_1,X_2,\cdots,X_i$ are pairwise independent, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_i^2] & = \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^i X_j ight)^2 ight] \ & = \sum_{j=1}^i \mathbb{E}[X_j^2] + 2 \sum_{j<k} \mathbb{E}[X_j X_k]\ & = \sum_{j=1}^i \mathbb{E}[X_j^2] + 2 \sum_{j<k} \mathbb{E}[X_j] \mathbb{E}[X_k]\ & = i \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

$(\mathbb{E}[H_i])^2 = \mathbb{E}[H_i^2] - \mathbb{D}[H_i]$ that means $(\mathbb{E}[H_i])^2 \leq \mathbb{E}[H_i^2] = i$. Thus $\mathbb{E}[H_i] \leq \sqrt{i}$.

  1. We will show $\mathbb{E}[H_i] > C \sqrt{i}, C= e^{-1} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}}$ by induction (It’s clear $0<C<1$)

Base case: For $i=1$, we know $\mathbb{E}[H_1] = \vert 1 \vert \cdot rac{1}{2}+\vert -1 \vert \cdot rac{1}{2} = 1 > C \sqrt{1}$. And for $i=2$, we know $\mathbb{E}[H_2] = \vert 2 \vert \cdot rac{1}{4} +\vert -2 \vert \cdot rac{1}{4} + 0 \cdot rac{1}{2} = 1 > rac{\sqrt{2}}{e} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}} = C \sqrt{2} $.\

Induction Hypothesis: $\mathbb{E}[H_j] > rac{\sqrt{j}}{2}, orall j \leq k$

We will show ${\mathbb{E}[H_{k+1}] > rac{\sqrt{k+1}}{2}}$ in the following

  • If $k+1$ is even: By Lemma 1, $\mathbb{E}[H_{k+1}] = \mathbb{E}[H_{k}] = \mathbb{E}[H_{k-1}] + rac{1}{2^{k-1}} inom{k-1}{(k-1)/2} $. Then, we have
\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{1}{2^{k-1}} inom{k-1}{(k-1)/2} & = rac{1}{2^{k-1}} rac{(k-1)!}{\left(\left( rac{k-1}{2} ight)! ight)^2} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

By Stirling formula, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{1}{2^{k-1}} inom{k-1}{(k-1)/2} & = rac{1}{2^{k-1}} rac{(k-1)!}{\left(\left( rac{k-1}{2} ight)! ight)^2} \ & > rac{1}{2^{k-1}} rac{\sqrt{2 \pi (k-1)} \left( rac{k-1}{e} ight)^{k-1}}{\pi (k-1) \left( rac{k-1}{2e} ight)^{k-1} e^ rac{1}{12(k-1)}}\ & = e^{- rac{1}{12(k-1)}} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}} rac{1}{\sqrt{k-1}}\ & > e^{-1} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}} rac{1}{\sqrt{k-1}}\ & = e^{-1} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}} rac{2}{2\sqrt{k-1}}> C rac{2}{\sqrt{k+1} + \sqrt{k-1}} = C (\sqrt{k+1} - \sqrt{k-1}) \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

By induction hypothesis, $\mathbb{E}[H_{k-1}] > C\sqrt{k-1}$, that means

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_{k+1}] &= \mathbb{E}[H_{k}] \ &= \mathbb{E}[H_{k-1}] + rac{1}{2^{k-1}} inom{k-1}{(k-1)/2}\ & > C\sqrt{k-1} + C (\sqrt{k+1} - \sqrt{k-1}) \ & = C \sqrt{k+1} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]
  • If $k+1$ is odd: By Lemma 1, $\mathbb{E}[H_{k+1}] = \mathbb{E}[H_{k}] + rac{1}{2^{k}} inom{k}{k/2} $. Then, we have
\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{1}{2^{k}} inom{k}{k/2} & = rac{1}{2^{k}} rac{k!}{\left(\left( rac{k}{2} ight)! ight)^2} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

By Stirling formula, we have

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{1}{2^{k}} inom{k}{k/2} & > rac{1}{2^{k}} rac{\sqrt{2 \pi k} \left( rac{k}{e} ight)^{k}}{\pi k \left( rac{k}{2e} ight)^{k} e^ rac{1}{12k}}\ & > e^{-1} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}} rac{1}{\sqrt{k}}\ & > e^{-1} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}} rac{1}{2\sqrt{k}}> C rac{1}{\sqrt{k+1} + \sqrt{k}} = C (\sqrt{k+1} - \sqrt{k}) \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

By induction hypothesis, $\mathbb{E}[H_{k}] > C\sqrt{k}$, that means

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[H_{k+1}] &= \mathbb{E}[H_{k}] + rac{1}{2^{k}} inom{k}{k/2}\ & > C\sqrt{k} + C (\sqrt{k+1} - \sqrt{k}) \ & = C \sqrt{k+1} \end{aligned} onumber \end{equation}\]

Hence, we show $\mathbb{E}[H_i] > C \sqrt{i}, C= e^{-1} \sqrt{ rac{2}{\pi}}$, and $\mathbb{E}[H_i] \leq \sqrt{i}$, which imply $\mathbb{E}[H_i] = \Theta(\sqrt{i})$. $\square$
